Expectation1: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation1: The ambulance driver is on standby at the station, ready for any new dispatch to come in.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: They appear at a minor hearing where the stakes are relatively low
Story: I sat in the courthouse, my suit feeling stiff and unfamiliar after a week of night shifts behind the wheel. The judge called my client’s name, and I stood, ready to represent him in this minor hearing. My mind was half on the case, half on the radio clipped to my belt—protocol said I had to keep it on, just in case. I knew the expectation: as an ambulance driver, I had to respond instantly, no matter where I was. But as an advocate, my client deserved my full attention, my best arguments, my presence in the moment. The hearing was routine, but to my client, it mattered. I could see his nervous hands, the way he looked to me for reassurance. Suddenly, the radio crackled—an emergency call, a child in distress, just blocks away. My heart pounded. I felt the weight of two worlds pressing in, each demanding I drop everything for them. I gripped my briefcase, torn between the courtroom and the siren’s call, knowing I could not be in both places at once.
